issues.title: AttributeError: 'FunctionCall' object has no attribute 'role' [V1.03]
issues.body:
When: Occurs within the livekit-agents framework, specifically in the livekit.plugins.turn_detector.eou.predict_end_of_turn function called via livekit.agents.voice.audio_recognition.py's _bounce_eou_task. This happens after a user speaks, seemingly following an interaction involving a **tool call**

Indication: The internal chat context (chat_ctx) being processed by the End-of-Utterance turn detector contains a raw FunctionCall object where a standard message object (with a .role) is expected. The turn detector plugin cannot handle this object type in the message history.

issues.title: Dynamically add `ai_callable` methods to function contexts
issues.body:
<!--
Hello! Thanks for taking the time to ask a question.

Before creating this issue, we kindly ask that you use the search functionality
to see if anyone else has already asked this question.
Please include details such as environment, package versions, minimal examples,
and error logs, if applicable.

Feel free to join us in the #agents channel on our Slack, and ask your question
there to get quicker help from us and the community:

https://livekit.io/join-slack
-->
I'm not sure if this is a feature request or a question, as I don't know if it's already a supported use case.

## Description

Currently, you can use `@llm.ai_callable()` to make a method in a `llm.FunctionContext` callable by the agent.

```python
class CallActions(llm.FunctionContext):
    """
    Detect user intent and perform actions
    """

    def __init__(
        self, *, api: api.LiveKitAPI, participant: rtc.RemoteParticipant, room: rtc.Room
    ):
        super().__init__()

        self.api = api
        self.participant = participant
        self.room = room

    async def hangup(self):
        try:
            await self.api.room.remove_participant(
                api.RoomParticipantIdentity(
                    room=self.room.name,
                    identity=self.participant.identity,
                )
            )
        except Exception as e:
            # it's possible that the user has already hung up, this error can be ignored
            logger.info(f"received error while ending call: {e}")

    @llm.ai_callable()
    async def end_call(self):
        """Called when the user wants to end the call"""
        logger.info(f"ending the call for {self.participant.identity}")
        await self.hangup()
```

However, these methods are fixed (defined together with the class). I'd like to dynamically add a callable method to the instance at runtime.

```python
    call_actions = CallActions(api=ctx.api, participant=participant, room=ctx.room)

    async def end_call(self: CallActions):
        """Called when the user wants to end the call"""
        logger.info(f"ending the call for {self.participant.identity}")
        await self.hangup()

    # Add `end_call` to `call_actions`
```

How would I do that?

## Alternatives

Not that I know of. I was able to hack my way through it, looking to the implementation of `ai_callable`, but I hardly think it's something you should be doing.

```python
    call_actions = CallActions(api=ctx.api, participant=participant, room=ctx.room)

    async def end_call(self: CallActions):
        """Called when the user wants to end the call"""
        logger.info(f"ending the call for {self.participant.identity}")
        await self.hangup()

    # Set the metadata using the internal mechanism
    llm.function_context._set_metadata(
        end_call,
        name="end_call",
        desc="Called when the user wants to end the call",
        auto_retry=False
    )

    # Bind it to the instance
    bound_method = types.MethodType(end_call, call_actions)

    # Register it with the function context system
    call_actions._fncs["end_call"] = llm.function_context.FunctionInfo(
        name="end_call",
        description="Called when the user wants to end the call",
        auto_retry=False,
        callable=bound_method,
        arguments={}  # No arguments besides self
    )

    # Set it as an instance method
    call_actions.end_call = bound_method
```

issues.title: Cannot initialize `VoicePipelineAgent` without a VAD
issues.body:
<!--
Hello! Thanks for taking the time to file a bug report.

Before creating this issue, we kindly ask that you use the search functionality
to see if anyone else has already reported this issue.
Please include details such as environment, package versions, minimal examples,
and error logs, if applicable.
-->

The OpenAI STT plugin has been updated to support both `server_vad` and `semantic_vad`, but when instantiating a `VoicePipelineAgent` object you must provide a VAD parameter (ie the Silero model). If you are trying to use OpenAI turn taking this model is not required since the API handles turn taking on its own.

Similar issues exist for other plugings (ie Deepgram has Endpointing support which is equally blocked by this VAD param)

issues.title: TTS transcription is still sent after "agentStoppedSpeaking" and "agentSpeechInterrupted"
issues.body:
Upon interrupting the agent while he is talking, the events `agentStoppedSpeaking` and `agentSpeechInterrupted` are fired.
Though after that a TTS transcription is still being sent. 

I can see this in my frontend by receiving the TTS transcription events: 
> RoomEvent.TranscriptionReceived, (transcriptions, participant)

And our VoicePipelineAgent-Pipeline also sends RPC's to the client when `agentStoppedSpeaking` and `agentSpeechInterrupted` is triggered, so the frontend can see when this happens too.

issues.title: How can I handle LLM errors?
issues.body:
## Question
Is it currently possible to provide a custom error handler for LLM requests? 

## Context
I'm building a voice agent (`VoicePipelineAgent`) using the latest version of both `livekit-agents` and `livekit-plugins-azure` and Azure as the only provider for all stages of the pipeline (LLM, TTS and STT).

For reference:

```python
assistant = VoicePipelineAgent(
    vad=ctx.proc.userdata["vad"],
    stt=stt.STT(
        speech_key=settings.AZURE_SPEECH_KEY,
        speech_region=settings.AZURE_SPEECH_REGION,
        language="es-ES",
        languages=["es-ES"]
    ),
    llm=openai.LLM.with_azure(
        model="gpt-4o",
        azure_endpoint=settings.AZURE_OPENAI_ENDPOINT,
        azure_deployment=settings.AZURE_OPENAI_DEPLOYMENT,
        api_version=settings.AZURE_OPENAI_API_VERSION,
        api_key=settings.AZURE_OPENAI_API_KEY,
        temperature=settings.LLM_TEMPERATURE,
    ),
    tts=azure.TTS(
        speech_region=settings.AZURE_SPEECH_REGION,
        voice="es-ES-LiaNeural",
        language="es-ES"
    ),
    min_endpointing_delay=0.7,
    interrupt_speech_duration=1.2,
    max_nested_fnc_calls=3,
    preemptive_synthesis=True,
    chat_ctx=initial_ctx,
    fnc_ctx=AssistantToolContext(ctx, participant)
)
```

## Problem

We rely on the Azure OpenAI Service so all inputs and outputs (to and from the LLM) are heavily moderated and the chance of some random sentence being flagged as inappropriate is always non-zero even if we set the moderation to a minimum.  We suspect the root cause is the poor performance of OpenAI's moderation classifiers in non-english languages, flagging some messages as "sexual" or "self-harm" in a pretty standard conversation.

In practice, requesting a completion with an "inappropriate" (again, not inappropriate by any means but flagged as such) word/sentence on it results in a 400 status code, which gets handled by `livekit-agents` on [this line](https://github.com/livekit/agents/blob/c7881f3776faa2dc4cea0bda4fd832173c00ac17/livekit-agents/livekit/agents/llm/llm.py#L146) in the `LLMStream` class. 

For reference, this is how it looks like in the logs

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/livekit/agents/llm/llm.py", line 149, in _main_task
    return await self._run()
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/livekit/plugins/openai/llm.py", line 767, in _run
    raise APIStatusError(
livekit.agents._exceptions.APIStatusError: Error code: 400 - {'error': {'message': "The response was filtered due to the prompt triggering Azure OpenAI's content management policy. Please modify your prompt and retry. To learn more about our content filtering policies please read our documentation: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2198766", 'type': None, 'param': 'prompt', 'code': 'content_filter', 'status': 400, 'innererror': {'code': 'ResponsibleAIPolicyViolation', 'content_filter_result': {'hate': {'filtered': False, 'severity': 'safe'}, 'jailbreak': {'filtered': False, 'detected': False}, 'self_harm': {'filtered': False, 'severity': 'safe'}, 'sexual': {'filtered': True, 'severity': 'medium'}, 'violence': {'filtered': False, 'severity': 'safe'}}}}}
failed to generate LLM completion, retrying in 5.0s
```

This causes a chain of errors (because the same message is being sent over and over again) which ultimately prevent the agent from producing any output and a broken conversation state (because the user expects a response that never arrives and the agent just waits for a new human message because its turn is done).

After some research, it looks like the only error handling is done on the [`_main_task`](https://github.com/livekit/agents/blob/c7881f3776faa2dc4cea0bda4fd832173c00ac17/livekit-agents/livekit/agents/llm/llm.py#L146) method of the `LLMStream` class and it's just a simple retry loop with a delay between attempts.


## Proposal

If this isn't already implemented, I would like to propose an implementation for a new error handling mechanism. 

Ideally, I would be able to provide a custom handler that gets called whenever the API returns an error. This would be provided as a parameter to the `VoicePipelineAgent` in the same way other callbacks are provided.


```python
VoicePipelineAgent(
    on_llm_error=...,
    ...
)
```

The provided callback would likely receive the `LLMStream` implementation (for example, the [OpenAI one](https://github.com/livekit/agents/blob/c7881f3776faa2dc4cea0bda4fd832173c00ac17/livekit-plugins/livekit-plugins-openai/livekit/plugins/openai/llm.py#L669) when using OpenAI-compatible services) although I'm not sure if this is the most intuitive interface or how this would work in practice. In any case, the proposed `on_llm_error` callback must be able to determine if the agent makes the same completion request again, changes the message contents or returns a default message (the same way it's currently being done with tools, where a default message can be "said" using the `.say()` method).

If no `on_llm_error` callback is provided, the current [`_main_task`](https://github.com/livekit/agents/blob/c7881f3776faa2dc4cea0bda4fd832173c00ac17/livekit-agents/livekit/agents/llm/llm.py#L146) can be used instead, making this an opt-in feature

What are your thoughts about this? I can work on this myself if it ends up being useful and once (if) we agree on the best approach
issues.author: rmonvfer

from your handler, what would you like to do with the error? would it have a similar interface to `before_llm_cb` so that we could initiate an alternative completion?

another related item: we have a Fallback

As to what happens inside the call

issues.title: function calling with new openai STT introduces partial or unexpected results
issues.body:
Hello,
I wrote some comments on it here, but it was already closed so might be missed:

https://github.com/livekit/agents/issues/1703

If use function calling, AssistantFnc and expect some Annotated str to be added into the function call (in this case as spoken code such as P010200 in various ways and tempo) the new openAI STT class seems to produce much worse str params into the function that previous. 
One would expect the new transcribe  with much less WER on all language to be even better. But even if i use whisper-1 it returns worse results that current with using the whispermodel.

openai_stt = stt.STT(
        language="sv",
         model="whisper-1",
    )

changing 
_delta_transcript_interval to some higher value in
https://github.com/livekit/agents/blob/f11d7b34d9c26a2ca8b64049408d7f3df674e653/livekit-plugins/livekit-plugins-openai/livekit/plugins/openai/stt.py

Seems to get a bit better, but it is a hit-miss.
issues.author: lundin

comments.author: davidzhao
comments.body:
that's rather unexpected to hear about the result. have you tried testing with the new GPT-4o models? they should produce a higher transcription accuracy compared to whisper.

two things here:
1. you can revert back to the old behavior by constructing the STT with `use_realtime=False`.
2. `_delta_tr

comments.body: Thanks a lot @davidzhao i think i feel same level of correctnes now again with "gpt-4o-transcribe" and use_realtime=False :)

issues.title: OpenAI S2S Error: Your session hit the maximum duration of 15 minutes.
issues.body:
I'm looking to run sessions in the 30+ minutes range and need to handle disconnects more gracefully, especially a timeout where it is inevitable at the 15 minute mark.

Would be great if the SDK could create a new connection, pass the messages across (assuming they fit in the context window) and restart the conversation seamlessly.

issues.title: Bot is speaking and listening at the same time? user cannot interrupt bot, but bot should not ignore user
issues.body:
I want bot always listen to user's voice regardless of who is speaking. I'm using `VoicePipelineAgent` 

if I set `allow_interruptions=False`, Bot won't listen any more once user has finished the sentence. 

If I set `allow_interruptions=True`, Bot will stop talking when user starts speaking while bot is also speaking.

I don't want user to be able to interrupt bot, but bot should not ignore user when bot and user are both speaking. User's speech can be appended in the history. This is the behaviour of openai's read-time API when setting interruptions to False.

How do I achieve this with `VoicePipelineAgent` ?

Dear Livekit team,

my company has a it's own real-time video avatar model and would like to use the abstraction of `VoicePipelineAgent` to run it with different LLMs and your implementation of function calls. (the current demo on your repo only shows how to send video directly to room, not how to use an agent that produces video)

A natural place to plug something like this in would be to extend the `tts` component with video-frame generation or subclass `VoicePipelineAgent` so that it requires an additional `avatar`  service that is fed with the chunks produced by `tts`. Would you be willing to provide an example/stub that does that or guide me in how to best implement this?

issues.title: I have 2 agents in agent.py, when a agent is speaking, how do I tell which one is speaking on the frontend?
issues.body:
I have 2 agents like this

```python
caller_agent = VoicePipelineAgent(...)
recipient_agent = VoicePipelineAgent(...)

caller_agent.start(ctx.room, caller)
recipient_agent.start(ctx.room, recipient)
```

both `caller_agent` and `recipient_agent` might share context so I cannot invite 2 agent.py.

When any agent is speaking, it shows the same identity on the frontend. How do I tell which one is actually speaking?

comments.author: davidzhao
comments.body:
you'd want to create a new Room object and connecting it to it directly, instead of trying to reuse the same connection.

a new Room objet will allow you to connect to it again, as the second agent.

comments.author: stevemao
comments.body: @davidzhao how do these 2 rooms share the same state (context)?

comments.body: And also both users need to hear both agents

comments.author: davidzhao
comments.body:
make sure the second agent also joins the same room..

though please be warned, while multi-user interactions are possible, we have yet to optimize the framework for that use case. You may end up having to build a few more pieces on your own in order to achieve the right experience.

comments.author: stevemao
comments.body: Also a new room will double the cost for us.

issues.title: What is the right way to retrieve users data before function call?
issues.body:
Hi. I am new to Livekit agents.

I want to query my database for users information before calling a function.

For example:
- For weather function from the example, i first want to check in the database if I already have the users location stored before asking them for their location to get the weather for. 

How can I achieve this?

The flow should be--
- User asks for weather.
- We first check if we have the users location stored in the database.
 -- If yes, we pass the location to the weather function without asking user for their location.
 -- If no, we ask the user for their location and then pass the location to the weather function.

I tried passing in the entire conversation history to the chat context, and it cant pick the references of location from the chat history either.
issues.author: thebishalniroula

comments.author: longcw
comments.body: you can just trigger a function call for any ask for weather, and the location is an optional arg of the function. If no location provided, query the database in the function call.

@longcw  I think the focus of the question is:

- can the agent talk to the user while performing the function?

issues.title: Returning False to before_llm_cb() does not reset internal transcript buffer
issues.body:
## Title: VoicePipelineAgent retains and concatenates transcripts across turns even when returning False from before_llm_cb

### Description
When implementing a voice assistant using `VoicePipelineAgent`, I've discovered that the agent's speech recognition system concatenates user utterances across multiple turns, even when explicitly returning `False` from `before_llm_cb`. This behavior makes it impossible to handle each utterance independently when building a state machine or similar conversation flow manager.

### Observed Behavior
1. First turn:
   - User speaks: "Apple."
   - `before_llm_cb` receives: "Apple."
   - We return `False` from `before_llm_cb`
2. Second turn:
   - User speaks: "Barry."
   - `before_llm_cb` receives: "Apple. Barry."
   - We return `False` from `before_llm_cb`
3. Third turn:
   - User speaks: "Cherry."
   - `before_llm_cb` receives: "Apple. Barry. Cherry."
   - We return `False` from `before_llm_cb`

### Expected Behavior
According to the documentation, returning `False` from `before_llm_cb` should "cancel the synthesis of the reply" and presumably reset the speech processing pipeline. Each turn should only contain the current user utterance:
- First turn: "Apple."
- Second turn: "Barry."
- Third turn: "Cherry."

### Investigation Findings
Looking at the VoicePipelineAgent implementation, the issue appears to be in the internal `_transcribed_text` buffer which accumulates transcripts over time but is never reset when `before_llm_cb` returns `False`.

In `pipeline_agent.py`, the `_on_final_transcript` method concatenates new transcripts to this buffer:
```python
self._transcribed_text += (" " if self._transcribed_text else "") + new_transcript
```

However, when `before_llm_cb` returns `False`, this buffer is never cleared, causing all future transcripts to include previous utterances.

### Reproduction Steps
1. Create a minimal VoicePipelineAgent implementation
2. Add a `before_llm_cb` that logs the received user message and returns `False`
3. Have a user make multiple short, separate utterances
4. Observe the concatenation in the logs

### Workarounds Attempted
1. Clearing the agent's chat context after each turn
2. Setting `chat_ctx.messages[-1].content = ""` in `before_llm_cb`
3. Popping the last message with `chat_ctx.messages.pop()`
4. Maintaining a separate conversation history
5. Explicitly returning `False` from `before_llm_cb` after each user utterance

None of these approaches prevent the concatenation.

### Current Workaround
Currently, the only workaround is to manually reset the private attributes at the end of the `before_llm_cb` function:
```
```python
async def before_llm_cb(agent, chat_ctx):
    # Process message...
    
    # Reset the internal transcript buffer
    agent._transcribed_text = ""
    agent._transcribed_interim_text = ""
    
    return False
```
```

This works but relies on internal implementation details that could change.

### Proposed Solution
When `before_llm_cb` returns `False`, VoicePipelineAgent should reset its internal transcript buffers (`_transcribed_text` and `_transcribed_interim_text`) to ensure the next turn starts fresh.

### Technical Details
- **LiveKit Version**: 0.12.8
- **RTC Version**: 0.19.1
- **STT Component**: Deepgram STT (nova-3-general)

issues.title: LiveKit Agent on Google Cloud Run Fails with Initialization Timeout: Container Terminating Prematurely
issues.body: I've deployed a LiveKit Agent as a containerized service on Google Cloud Run, but I'm experiencing issues where the agent becomes unresponsive and fails to handle client requests. After examining the server logs, I've identified that the agent appears to hang indefinitely. Here is my code: ``` import os from dotenv import load_dotenv from livekit.agents import AutoSubscribe, JobContext, WorkerOptions, WorkerType, cli, multimodal, JobProcess, pipeline from livekit.plugins import google load_dotenv() LIVEKIT_URL = os.getenv("LIVEKIT_URL") OPENAI_API_KEY = os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY") HEALTHCHECK_PORT = os.getenv("HEALTHCHECK_PORT") GOOGLE_API_KEY = os.getenv("GOOGLE_API_KEY") async def entrypoint(ctx: JobContext): # connect agent await ctx.connect(auto_subscribe=AutoSubscribe.AUDIO_ONLY) print(f"Agent connected to room: {ctx.room.name}") participant = await ctx.wait_for_participant() print(f"Participant {participant.name} joined") voice_actor = 'Aoede' agent = multimodal.MultimodalAgent( model=google.beta.realtime.RealtimeModel( api_key=GOOGLE_API_KEY, voice=voice_actor, temperature=0.8, instructions=participant.attributes["system_instruction"], modalities=["AUDIO"], model="gemini-2.0-flash-exp", )) agent.start(ctx.room, participant) print("Multimodal agent started and ready for interaction.") # await asyncio.Future() if __name__ == "__main__": opts = WorkerOptions(entrypoint_fnc=entrypoint, worker_type=WorkerType.ROOM, port=HEALTHCHECK_PORT) cli.run_app(opts) ```

issues.title: Allow custom logger configuration in livekit.agents.cli.run_app
issues.body:
Currently, run_app calls setup_logging internally, either in development (colored logs) or production (JSON logs). However, this forces a logging configuration on the user, making it difficult to integrate with existing logging setups.

It would be helpful to have an option to:

Disable the automatic logging setup.
Provide a custom logging configuration before run_app initializes its own.
Is there currently a way to override this behavior? If not, would it be possible to introduce a configuration flag or allow users to define their own logger before setup_logging is executed?

This would make integration with existing logging pipelines much more flexible.

Thanks!

issues.title: Track Publication Timeout in Certain room.on Callbacks
issues.body:
#### **Description**
I've encountered a strange issue when trying to publish a video and audio track user the `play_video` function below when inside a `room.on` callback. The function works correctly with the `track_published` and `track_unpublished` event callbacks, but **fails with a timeout** when called from `data_received` or `participant_attributes_changed` events.

The error I get:
```
livekit.rtc.participant.PublishTrackError: room error engine: internal error: track publication timed out, no response received from the server
```
Interestingly, if I **do not publish the audio track**, it works fine in all cases and publishes the video successfuly.

---

#### **Expected Behavior**
Publishing the video and audio track should work regardless of which event callback triggers `play_video()`.

#### **Actual Behavior**
- âœ… Works inside `track_published` and `track_unpublished`
- âŒ Fails inside `data_received` and `participant_attributes_changed`
- âœ… Works in all cases if the audio track is not published

---

#### **Steps to Reproduce**
1. Create a function to publish video and audio tracks (see `play_video` below).
2. Call this function from different `room.on` event callbacks (see _on_track_published implementation as an example).
3. Observe that it works in some cases but times out in others.

---

#### **Relevant Code**
##### **Callback Function Example**
```python
room.on("track_published",self._on_track_published)

def _on_track_published(self, publication: rtc.RemoteTrackPublication, participant: rtc.RemoteParticipant):
    logger.info("Track Published")
    asyncio.create_task(self.play_video())
```

##### **`play_video()` Implementation**
```python
async def play_video(self):
    try:
        self._media_streamer = LivekitMediaStreamer(
            media_file=MEDIA_PATH,
            resample_sample_rate=22000,
        )
        media_info = self._media_streamer.info

        # Create video and audio sources/tracks
        self._video_source = rtc.VideoSource(
            width=media_info.video_width,
            height=media_info.video_height,
        )
        logger.info(media_info)
        self._audio_source = rtc.AudioSource(
            sample_rate=media_info.audio_sample_rate,
            num_channels=media_info.audio_channels,
            queue_size_ms=BUFFER_SIZE_MS,
        )
        video_track = rtc.LocalVideoTrack.create_video_track("video", self._video_source)
        audio_track = rtc.LocalAudioTrack.create_audio_track("audio", self._audio_source)

        # Publish tracks
        video_options = rtc.TrackPublishOptions(
            source=rtc.TrackSource.SOURCE_CAMERA,
            video_encoding=rtc.VideoEncoding(
                max_framerate=30,
                max_bitrate=5_000_000,
            ),
        )
        audio_options = rtc.TrackPublishOptions(source=rtc.TrackSource.SOURCE_MICROPHONE)

        await self._job_context.room.local_participant.publish_track(video_track, video_options)
        await self._job_context.room.local_participant.publish_track(audio_track, audio_options)

        media_info = self._media_streamer.info

        self._av_sync = rtc.AVSynchronizer(
            audio_source=self._audio_source,
            video_source=self._video_source,
            video_fps=media_info.video_fps,
            video_queue_size_ms=BUFFER_SIZE_MS,
        )

        self._media_streamer.reset()

        video_stream = self._media_streamer.stream_video()
        audio_stream = self._media_streamer.stream_audio()

        # Read the head frames and push them at the same time
        first_video_frame, video_timestamp = await video_stream.__anext__()
        first_audio_frame, audio_timestamp = await audio_stream.__anext__()
        logger.info(
            f"first video duration: {1 / media_info.video_fps:.3f}s, "
            f"first audio duration: {first_audio_frame.duration:.3f}s"
        )
        await self._av_sync.push(first_video_frame, video_timestamp)
        await self._av_sync.push(first_audio_frame, audio_timestamp)

        video_task = asyncio.create_task(self._push_frames(video_stream, self._av_sync))
        audio_task = asyncio.create_task(self._push_frames(audio_stream, self._av_sync))

        log_fps_task = asyncio.create_task(self._log_fps(self._av_sync))

        # Wait for both tasks to complete
        await asyncio.gather(video_task, audio_task)
        await self._av_sync.wait_for_playout()

        # Clean up
        self._av_sync.reset()
        log_fps_task.cancel()
        logger.info("Playout finished")

    finally:
        if self._media_streamer:
            await self._media_streamer.aclose()
        if self._av_sync:
            await self._av_sync.aclose()
        if self._audio_source:
            await self._audio_source.aclose()
        if self._video_source:
            await self._video_source.aclose()
```

---

#### **Error Output**
```
livekit.rtc.participant.PublishTrackError: room error engine: internal error: track publication timed out, no response received from the server
```

[livestreamer_implementation.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19088626/livestreamer_implementation.txt)

issues.title: on("disconnected") Event Not Triggering Consistently in Python SDK on Unexpected Process Exits
issues.body:
### Description
While building an application using the LiveKit Agents Python SDK, I noticed that the `on("disconnected")` event wasnâ€™t firing reliably when the process exited unexpectedly. My app depends on this event to send a conversation transcript to a feedback endpoint during cleanup. In cases where the process exit log showed a blank `"reason"` field, the event didnâ€™t trigger at all, leaving my cleanup logic stranded. This became a real headache as I couldnâ€™t guarantee the transcript would always be sent.


**Steps to Reproduce**:  
1. Set up a basic agent using the Python SDK with a `JobContext` and a room connection.
2. Register an `on("disconnected")` handler:
   ```python
   @ctx.room.on("disconnected")
   def on_disconnected(reason: str):
       print(f"Disconnected. Reason: {reason}")
   ```
3. Force an abrupt process termination (e.g., `kill -TERM <pid>` or network failure simulation).
4. Observe logs and handler execution.

**Expected Behavior**:  
The `on("disconnected")` event should fire consistently with a meaningful `reason` whenever the room disconnects, even during unexpected process exits, allowing cleanup logic to run.

**Actual Behavior**:  
- In normal cases (e.g., room closed properly), the event fires with `"reason": "room disconnected"`.
- In failing cases (e.g., abrupt termination), the process exits with `"reason": ""` in the log, and the event does not trigger. Example logs:
  - Failing: `{"message": "process exiting", "reason": "", "timestamp": "2025-02-25T21:29:38.331188+00:00"}`
  - Working: `{"message": "process exiting", "reason": "room disconnected", "timestamp": "2025-02-25T15:40:25.786824+00:00"}`

**Workaround**:  
Using a `try/finally` block to monitor `ctx.room.connection_state` and force cleanup:
```python
try:
    while ctx.room.connection_state == rtc.ConnectionState.CONNECTED:
        await asyncio.sleep(1)
finally:
    await handle_disconnection()
```
This works but bypasses the event-driven design. The LiveKit team suggested â€œshutdown hooksâ€ as a more reliable alternative, but specific guidance is unclear.

**Proposed Fix**:  
- Ensure the `on("disconnected")` event is triggered consistently by hooking into process shutdown signals (e.g., SIGTERM) within the SDK.
- Alternatively, expose a clear shutdown hook API in `JobContext` (e.g., `ctx.on_shutdown(callback)`) that developers can use for cleanup, guaranteed to run on process exit.

**Questions**:  
1. Is the blank `"reason"` a known issue tied to WebRTC connection drops or process termination timing?
2. Are there existing shutdown hooks in the SDK we should use instead? If so, please document them.

**Impact**:  
This affects applications relying on disconnection events for critical cleanup, like sending data to external endpoints. A reliable solution would improve the SDKâ€™s robustness.
issues.author: shwetd19

comments.author: davidzhao
comments.body: any reasons the [shutdown hook](https://docs.livekit.io/agents/build/session/#post-processing-and-cleanup) doesn't work for your needs?

comments.author: shwetd19
comments.body: Thanks for pointing me to the [shutdown hook](https://docs.livekit.io/agents/build/session/#post-processing-and-cleanup)â€”it does solve the issue for basic cleanup. That said, itâ€™d be great if we could pair it with a fix for the `on('disconnected')` event not triggering consistently in the Python SDK

issues.title: MultimodalAgent interrupts itself when response is created from function result
issues.body:
During the function call, the model could return audio letting the user know that it's performing an operation.

While that speech is being played back, if the function call finishes with the result, we would have created an additional response that would interrupt that speech:

For example:

```
Let's say I have a tool called turn_on_the_light.
The agent will say "I'll turn on the {cut-in}} the light is now on".
```

This is happening because of the `response.create()` line
```
if called_fnc.result is not None:
            self.conversation.item.create(tool_call, item_id)
            self.response.create()
```

We should wait until current speech handle is finished before queuing additional speech

issues.title: Dockerfile-example Fails to Build voice-pipeline-agent Due to Missing g++
issues.body:
### Description
When building a Docker image using the provided `examples/Dockerfile-example` with the `requirements.txt` from `examples/voice-pipeline-agent/`, the build fails due to a missing C++ compiler (`g++`). The error occurs while compiling the `annoy` package, which is a transitive dependency of one of the required packages (likely `livekit-plugins-silero` or similar).



### The build fails with the following error:
```
gcc: fatal error: cannot execute â€˜cc1plusâ€™: execvp: No such file or directory
compilation terminated.
error: command '/usr/bin/gcc' failed with exit code 1
ERROR: Failed building wheel for annoy
```


### Root Cause
- The `annoy` package requires C++ compilation (evident from `.cc` files in its build output).
- The `Dockerfile-example` installs `gcc` but not `g++`, which is needed to compile C++ code.

### Suggested Fix
Add `g++` to the `apt-get install` command in `examples/Dockerfile-example`:
```dockerfile
RUN apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y \
    gcc \
    g++ \
    python3-dev \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
```
### Additional Context
requirements.txt used: https://github.com/livekit/agents/blob/main/examples/voice-pipeline-agent/requirements.txt
Dockerfile: https://github.com/livekit/agents/blob/main/examples/Dockerfile-example
Tested with python:3.11.6-slim base image.


This seems like a small but impactful fix to make the example more robust. Happy to submit a PR if this aligns with the projectâ€™s goals!

issues.title: [dev] Persistent "agent started without audio or text output" Warning Despite TTS Integration
issues.body:
#### Description
I'm encountering a recurring warning in my LiveKit Agents application: `agent started without audio or text output`, even when using a valid TTS plugin (`cartesia.TTS`). The agent is configured to produce audio output via `say`, but the warning persists, suggesting a potential timing or initialization issue within `PipelineAgent`.

#### Minimal Example
```python
import asyncio
from livekit.agents import JobContext, WorkerOptions, WorkerType, cli
from livekit.agents.pipeline import PipelineAgent, AgentTask
from livekit.plugins import cartesia, deepgram, openai
import logging

logger = logging.getLogger("test-agent")
logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

class TestNode(AgentTask):
    async def on_enter(self):
        self.agent.say("Hello, testing audio output.")

async def entrypoint(ctx: JobContext):
    await ctx.connect()
    agent = PipelineAgent(
        task=TestNode(),
        stt=deepgram.STT(),
        llm=openai.LLM(),
        tts=cartesia.TTS(),
    )
    await agent.start()
    await asyncio.sleep(5)  # Keep running briefly

if __name__ == "__main__":
    cli.run_app(WorkerOptions(entrypoint_fnc=entrypoint, worker_type=WorkerType.ROOM))
```


#### Expected Behavior
- The agent starts without the warning since `cartesia.TTS` is configured and `say` is called shortly after `start()`.
- Audio output is produced for "Hello, testing audio output."

#### Actual Behavior
- The warning `agent started without audio or text output` appears in the logs despite a functional TTS setup.
- Audio is not being produced , but the warning still occurs.

#### Logs
```
2025-02-27 04:55:58,619 - WARNING livekit.agents - agent started without audio or text output {"pid": 24406, "job_id": "AJ_uJGDj2Fny5k6"}
2025-02-27 04:55:58,620 - INFO test-agent - Agent saying: Hello, testing audio output.
```

#### Additional Context
- The warning seems to occur because `PipelineAgent.start()` completes before the TTS system (e.g., Cartesia) is fully initialized.
- Adding a delay (e.g., `await asyncio.sleep(2)`) and forcing an initial `say` call after `start()` sometimes mitigates the issue, but this feels like a workaround rather than a proper fix.
issues.author: shwetd19

issues.title: [Bug?] Egress participant not triggering participant_connected event
issues.body:
This may or may not be a bug - I just want some clarification. 

I'm working on a unique system where i'm using egress to record rooms. I noticed there is a PARTICIPANT_KIND_EGRESS which from the name creates an impression that when egress occurs, a PARTICIPANT_KIND_EGRESS participant will join the room. In fact I confirmed though the Livekit Cloud logs that this is true. In the screenshot it shows that a participant with name "EG_{uuid}" is indeed added to the room after the agent joins. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5d3474a1-0fe0-4013-93af-dc1a1f038524)


My goal is to be notified when the egress user joins the room with the code
```
async def entrypoint(ctx: JobContext):
    ctx.room.on("participant_connected", lambda participant: logger.info("participant connected %s", participant))
    await ctx.connect(auto_subscribe=AutoSubscribe.AUDIO_ONLY)
```
I never see the egress user joining but recordings are being created as specified in my auto egress setup. 

Here's how I create my room:
```
  room = None
    try:
        room = await lkapi.room.create_room(CreateRoomRequest(
            name=room_name,
            max_participants=10,
            empty_timeout=120,
            egress=RoomEgress(
                room=RoomCompositeEgressRequest(
                    room_name=room_name,

                )

        ))
        print("room created", room)
    except Exception as e:
        print("error creating room", e)
    finally:
        # before your app exits or when the API client is no longer needed, you must close its session
        await lkapi.aclose()
```


Am i misunderstanding something?
issues.author: VictorAny

comments.author: davidzhao
comments.body:
Egress participants are not visible to others in the room. They have a `hidden` property bit set to ensure you don't accidentally start a conversation with an Egress participant

We do have a `room.isRecording` property that should get set when Egress is in the room. However, Python SDK currently ca

Got it -- that makes sense.

@davidzhao is this property available for the javascript client sdk?

issues.title: Solution to "InvalidStateError" and Handling of Closed Channels in OpenAI's AssistantLLMStream
issues.body:
Hello everyone,

Recently, we encountered an error while using the OpenAI Assistants API in our project. Upon investigation, we noticed that several discussions in the community highlighted similar issues experienced by other developers. Iâ€™d like to share our experience and the solution we implemented, hoping it will be helpful to those facing the same problem.

Error Description:

When interacting with the assistant, the program intermittently threw the following error:

`asyncio.exceptions.InvalidStateError: invalid state`

This error occurred in the `_main_task ` method of the `AssistantLLMStream `class within the "`assistant_llm.py`" file, specifically when trying to set the result of a `Future ` that had already been completed:

`self._done_future.set_result(None)`

Additionally, exceptions related to attempts to send data through a closed channel (`ChanClosed`) were also observed, causing data flow interruptions and the assistant to stop responding.

Cause of the Error:

1. State of the `Future`: The `InvalidStateError ` occurs when attempting to modify the state of a `Future ` that has already been completed or canceled. In our case, the `Future ` `self._done_future` could already be finished when `set_result(None)` was called.

2. Improper Exception Handling: Exceptions in asynchronous methods were not being properly managed, leading to attempts to send data through a closed channel and additional exceptions that impacted the program's stability.

Solution Implemented:

1. Check the State of the `Future ` Before Modifying It:

We added a verification step to ensure that the `Future` was not already completed before calling `set_result(None)`:

`finally:`
`    if not self._done_future.done():`
`        self._done_future.set_result(None)`
        
This prevents attempts to modify a `Future` in an invalid state, avoiding the `InvalidStateError`.

2. Proper Exception Handling and Channel Closure:

In the `_main_task` method, we added an `except` block to capture any exceptions during execution, set `self._exception`, and close the event channel `self._event_ch`. This ensures that the stream iterator is aware of the exception and handles the flow appropriately.

`except Exception as e:`
`    logger.error(f"Unexpected error in _main_task: {e}")`
`    self._exception = e`
`    self._event_ch.close()`
    
Additionally, in the `on_text_delta` method of the `EventHandler` class, we handled exceptions while sending data through the channel, ensuring the program flow is not interrupted if the channel is closed:

`async def on_text_delta(self, delta: TextDelta, snapshot: Text):`
`    try:`
`        assert self.current_run is not None`
`        self._event_ch.send_nowait(`
`            llm.ChatChunk(`
`                request_id=self.current_run.id,`
`                choices=[`
`                    llm.Choice(`
`                        delta=llm.ChoiceDelta(role="assistant", content=delta.value)`
`                    )`
`                ],`
`            )`
`        )`
`    except utils.aio.ChanClosed:`
`        # The channel is closed, no action needed`
`        pass`
`    except Exception as e:`
`        logger.error(f"Exception in on_text_delta: {e}")`
`        self._llm_stream._exception = e`
`        self._llm_stream._event_ch.close()`
        
Results:

After applying these changes, the `InvalidStateError` stopped occurring, and the assistant now functions correctly, responding consistently to user interactions. Proper exception handling and validation of asynchronous object states improved the stability and robustness of the application.

issues.title: Flag to better support simultaneous text-to-speech and speech-to-text
issues.body:
hi,
I have a usecase for realtime translation, but i noticed that when the agent is speaking, some of the stt transcripts are missing / not added to the chat context so the agent will not consider those for llm and tts. I had a look at the VoicepipelineAgent internals and noticed the below code
(btw I have these config set `allow_interruptions=False, preemptive_synthesis=True`)

```
def _validate_reply_if_possible(self) -> None:
        """Check if the new agent speech should be played"""

        if self._playing_speech and not self._playing_speech.interrupted:
            should_ignore_input = False
            if not self._playing_speech.allow_interruptions:
                should_ignore_input = True
                logger.debug(
                    "skipping validation, agent is speaking and does not allow interruptions",
                    extra={"speech_id": self._playing_speech.id},
                )
```

and

```
if should_ignore_input:
                self._transcribed_text = ""
                return
```


I understood the transcribed text is cleared here to allow more natural flow of conversation, to keep a clean chat history of agent replying to the correct speech input.
However this does not quite fit my use case which does not tolerate missing speech input. Would it be possible to add a flag to turn this off (clearing out the transcript while speaking)
issues.author: okharedia

comments.author: davidzhao
comments.body:
user speech is always flowing in.. and STT is always running. since LLM requires the full input to be ready in order to start inference, we would wait until the user has completed their turn before starting inference.

can you describe what transcripts you are missing?

comments.author: okharedia
longwQaQ
comments.body: @okharedia Hello, when allow_interruptions=False, my business also wants to retain user input as much as possible. Do you have any good solutions?

issues.title: [Docs]: JobContext does not contain publisher instance variable
issues.body:
In [the documentation](https://docs.livekit.io/agents/build/anatomy/#worker-type) regarding the anatomy of the agent, it is stated that: `For PUBLISHER jobs, the entrypoint function will be called once for each publisher in the room. The JobContext.publisher object will contain a RemoteParticipant representing that publisher.`

As far as I'm aware, examining the class definition for `JobContext` reveals that there is no `publisher` instance variable for accessing a `RemoteParticipant`. There is one for `JobRequest` but this is very different from `JobContext`. The docs should be updated to reflect this if this is no longer a feature. If I misunderstood or missed something in regards to this line please let me know.
issues.author: jmho

```python
from __future__ import annotations
import logging
from typing import Annotated
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import os

import smtplib
from email.message import EmailMessage

from livekit.agents import (
    AutoSubscribe,
    JobContext,
    WorkerOptions,
    WorkerType,
    cli,
    llm,
    multimodal,
)
from livekit.plugins import openai

load_dotenv()
logger = logging.getLogger("my-worker")
logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)

# print(os.getenv("LIVEKIT_URL"))
# print(os.getenv("LIVEKIT_API_KEY"))
# print(os.getenv("LIVEKIT_API_SECRET"))


def send_email(subject, body, to_email):
    msg = EmailMessage()
    msg.set_content(body)
    msg["Subject"] = subject
    msg["From"] = os.getenv("EMAIL")
    msg["To"] = to_email

    with smtplib.SMTP_SSL(os.getenv("SMTP"), 465) as smtp:
        smtp.login(os.getenv("EMAIL"), os.getenv("PASSWORD"))
        smtp.send_message(msg)


async def entrypoint(ctx: JobContext):
    logger.info("starting entrypoint")

    fnc_ctx = llm.FunctionContext()

    @fnc_ctx.ai_callable()
    async def emergency_email(
        location: Annotated[
            str,
            llm.TypeInfo(description="The location where to send help in emergency"),
        ],
    ):
        """Called when user asks to send help email in emergency. This function will send help email in emergency."""
        logger.info("sending help email in emergency")
        send_email(
            f"Urgent Help Needed at {location}",
            f"This is an emergency situation at {location}. Immediate assistance is required. Please send help as soon as possible to address the critical situation.",
            "arkodeep3404@gmail.com",
        )
        return "emergency help email sent successfully"

    await ctx.connect(auto_subscribe=AutoSubscribe.AUDIO_ONLY)
    participant = await ctx.wait_for_participant()

issues.title: Deepgram's keyterms should be keyterm, not the plural
issues.body:
<!--
Hello! Thanks for taking the time to file a bug report.

Before creating this issue, we kindly ask that you use the search functionality
to see if anyone else has already reported this issue.
Please include details such as environment, package versions, minimal examples,
and error logs, if applicable.
-->
livekit-plugins-deepgram = "0.6.19"

See: https://developers.deepgram.com/docs/keyterm

It's in `SpeechStream._connect_ws`:

```python3
    async def _connect_ws(self) -> aiohttp.ClientWebSocketResponse:
        live_config: dict[str, Any] = {
            "model": self._opts.model,
            "punctuate": self._opts.punctuate,
            "smart_format": self._opts.smart_format,
            "no_delay": self._opts.no_delay,
            "interim_results": self._opts.interim_results,
            "encoding": "linear16",
            "vad_events": True,
            "sample_rate": self._opts.sample_rate,
            "channels": self._opts.num_channels,
            "endpointing": False
            if self._opts.endpointing_ms == 0
            else self._opts.endpointing_ms,
            "filler_words": self._opts.filler_words,
            "profanity_filter": self._opts.profanity_filter,
        }
        if self._opts.keywords:
            live_config["keywords"] = self._opts.keywords
        if self._opts.keyterms:
            live_config["keyterms"] = self._opts.keyterms  # <-- should be `keyterm`, not `keyterms`

        if self._opts.language:
            live_config["language"] = self._opts.language
```

issues.title: Stream TTS can't  output PipelineTTSMetrics
issues.body:
**description:**
Stream TTS service can't output PipelineTTSMetrics,for example deepgramã€elevenlabsã€etc. but,Chunked TTS service can output PipelineTTSMetrics, for example openaiã€azure.
I read the underlying source codeï¼Œi found Stream TTS service not emit(metrics_collected). Chunked TTS service is wrapped StreamAdapterï¼Œemit(metrics_collected).

**test_code:**
```Python
import asyncio
import logging
import os

from dotenv import load_dotenv
from livekit import rtc
from livekit.agents import (
    AutoSubscribe,
    JobContext,
    JobProcess,
    WorkerOptions,
    cli,
    llm,
    metrics,
)
from livekit.agents.pipeline import VoicePipelineAgent
from livekit.plugins import deepgram, openai, silero
from py_zero.config import load_config
from voice_agent.config import Config

load_dotenv()
logger = logging.getLogger("voice-assistant")


def prewarm(proc: JobProcess):
    proc.userdata["vad"] = silero.VAD.load()


async def entrypoint(ctx: JobContext):
    config_name = os.environ.get("CONFIG_NAME", "etc/config.yaml")
    cfg = load_config(config_name, Config)

    initial_ctx = llm.ChatContext().append(
        role="system",
        text=(
            "You are a voice assistant created by LiveKit. Your interface with users will be voice. "
            "You should use short and concise responses, and avoiding usage of unpronouncable punctuation."
        ),
    )

    logger.info(f"connecting to room {ctx.room.name}")
    await ctx.connect(auto_subscribe=AutoSubscribe.AUDIO_ONLY)

    # wait for the first participant to connect
    participant = await ctx.wait_for_participant()
    logger.info(f"starting voice assistant for participant {participant.identity}")

    agent = VoicePipelineAgent(
        vad=ctx.proc.userdata["vad"],
        stt=deepgram.STT(model="nova-3-general", api_key=cfg.deepgram.key),
        llm=openai.LLM(api_key=cfg.openai.key),
        tts=deepgram.TTS(api_key=cfg.deepgram.key),
        chat_ctx=initial_ctx,
    )

    agent.start(ctx.room, participant)

    usage_collector = metrics.UsageCollector()

    @agent.on("metrics_collected")
    def _on_metrics_collected(mtrcs: metrics.AgentMetrics):
        metrics.log_metrics(mtrcs)
        usage_collector.collect(mtrcs)

    async def log_usage():
        summary = usage_collector.get_summary()
        logger.info(f"Usage: ${summary}")

    ctx.add_shutdown_callback(log_usage)

    # listen to incoming chat messages, only required if you'd like the agent to
    # answer incoming messages from Chat
    chat = rtc.ChatManager(ctx.room)

    async def answer_from_text(txt: str):
        chat_ctx = agent.chat_ctx.copy()
        chat_ctx.append(role="user", text=txt)
        stream = agent.llm.chat(chat_ctx=chat_ctx)
        await agent.say(stream)

    @chat.on("message_received")
    def on_chat_received(msg: rtc.ChatMessage):
        if msg.message:
            asyncio.create_task(answer_from_text(msg.message))

    await agent.say("Hey, how can I help you today?", allow_interruptions=True)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    cli.run_app(
        WorkerOptions(
            entrypoint_fnc=entrypoint,
            prewarm_fnc=prewarm,
            api_key="you api_key",
            api_secret="you_secret",
            ws_url="you ws_url",
        ),
    )

issues.title: `JobContext.add_shutdown_callback` incorrectly tests for number of arguments in `callback` callable
issues.body:
When a `callback` is a bound method, the expression `callback.__code__.co_argcount` has one extra argument, the `self`. So the test is incorrect in "bound method" cases.

Example:
```python
class Example:
    async def aclose(self):
        pass

example = Example()
callback = example.aclose
print(callback.__code__.co_argcount)  # 1
```
Your code:
```python
    def add_shutdown_callback(
        self,
        callback: Union[
            Callable[[], Coroutine[None, None, None]],
            Callable[[str], Coroutine[None, None, None]],
        ],
    ) -> None:
        """
        Add a callback to be called when the job is shutting down.
        Optionally the callback can take a single argument, the shutdown reason.
        """
        if callback.__code__.co_argcount > 0:
            self._shutdown_callbacks.append(callback)  # type: ignore
        else:

            async def wrapper(_: str) -> None:
                await callback()  # type: ignore

            self._shutdown_callbacks.append(wrapper)
```
appends the callback "as is" into the list, and later calls it like:
```python
callback("reason")
```
which causes error `TypeError: Example.aclose() takes 1 positional argument but 2 were given`
issues.author: tvrtkos

issues.title: Proper approach to stop and restart the VoicePipelineAgent
issues.body:
<!--
Hello! Thanks for taking the time to ask a question.

Before creating this issue, we kindly ask that you use the search functionality
to see if anyone else has already asked this question.
Please include details such as environment, package versions, minimal examples,
and error logs, if applicable.

Feel free to join us in the #agents channel on our Slack, and ask your question
there to get quicker help from us and the community:

https://livekit.io/join-slack
-->
Hi team,

We are creating a call receptionist AI with a function where the AI makes an outbound SIP call to invite someone into the room.

So, we need to "pause" the agent until the outbound call hangs up, but we couldn't figure out how to do this without using private fields.

It's that the `await agent.aclose()` of `VoicePipelineAgent` doesn't really close the agent, the `_main_atask`, STT and VAD are still running, and there's no practical way to restart the agent.

```python3
    async def aclose(self) -> None:
        """Close the voice assistant"""
        if not self._started:
            return

        self._room.off("participant_connected", self._on_participant_connected)
        await self._deferred_validation.aclose()
```

Also, it doesn't reset the `_started`, and the `_deferred_validation` will not be reinitiated by the `start()`.

Quitting the local participant could be a solution, but it's also a bit clunky. In this way, we need a dummy participant in the room for event handling, as the room should be deleted when the main participant leaves.

Do you have any recommendations for handling this approach?

I'm happy to make a PR for the first approach, which involves aclose an agent cleanly for reopening.

issues.title: _main_task gets a RuntimeError if it says something in before_llm_cb without waiting for the handle and we interrupt it
issues.body:
<!--
Hello! Thanks for taking the time to file a bug report.

Before creating this issue, we kindly ask that you use the search functionality
to see if anyone else has already reported this issue.
Please include details such as environment, package versions, minimal examples,
and error logs, if applicable.
-->
livekit-agent version: 0.12.13

It's that if in a `before_llm_cb` we do:
```python3
await agent.say(backchannel_str, allow_interruptions=True)
```

without waiting for the response, as otherwise we'll first wait for the speech then wait for the llm. However, if this got interrupted, `_main_task` will throw an error:
```
2025-02-15 12:25:51,603 - ERROR livekit.agents.pipeline - Error in _main_task
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/livekit/agents/utils/log.py", line 16, in async_fn_logs
    return await fn(*args, **kwargs)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/livekit/agents/pipeline/pipeline_agent.py", line 684, in _main_task
    await self._play_speech(speech)
  File ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/livekit/agents/pipeline/pipeline_agent.py", line 840, in _play_speech
    play_handle = synthesis_handle.play()
                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/livekit/agents/pipeline/agent_output.py", line 70, in play
    raise RuntimeError("synthesis was interrupted")
```

This is because in `VoicePipelineAgent._play_speech`:
```python3
        await self._agent_publication.wait_for_subscription()

        synthesis_handle = speech_handle.synthesis_handle
        if synthesis_handle.interrupted:  # <-- we check the interruption here
            return

        user_question = speech_handle.user_question

        # wait for all pre-added nested speech to be played
        while speech_handle.nested_speech_handles:
            await nested_speech_played.wait()  # <-- but it's interrupted here

        await playing_lock.acquire()
        play_handle = synthesis_handle.play()  # <-- so this will raise a RuntimeError
        join_fut = play_handle.join()
```
issues.author: wdhwg001

comments.author: longcw
comments.body: Thanks for debugging this. Here is a fix https://github.com/livekit/agents/pull/1504

issues.title: Auto-discover new frontend function calls (rpc register, unregister)
issues.body:
I am attempting to build an agent that leverages the openai-realtime voice approach, but have frontend rpc calling be registered & unregistered dynamically... and in the middle of a single user's input. 

From the docs: https://docs.livekit.io/agents/voice-agent/function-calling/ is it possible to have auto-discovery of the frontend RPC functions which are loaded. We want to dynamically load frontend actions based on which components are currently on the users screen. (e.g. the "insert text" function would only loaded up / shown to the agent if the "document" component was rendered, because there would be no way for the function to run unless the document component was available. Similarly the agent shouldn't "see" functions which can't be run on the frontend.)

Ideally, this auto-discovery of frontend actions should be dynamically updated in the middle of an agent run... e.g. the user asks for a document to be created and text to be inserted... the agent flow would be:

1. user asks "create a document and insert a poem into it" with no document UI component loaded
2. agent receives request and sees only 1 action available: "createDocument"
3. agent calls "createDocument" and waits for the response and re-checks what frontend actions may have been introduced... in this case the "createDocument" function created a document component which has an RPC register function... which then surfaces 2 actions available: "createDocument" and "insertText"
4. the agent would continue operating calling the "insertText" function and then voice response

I think it would be easy to use participant attributes for this, however. so in the frontend whenever you register/unregister just update a related attribute and then observe those on the agen

issues.title: High Latency in ElevenLabs TTS Streaming Due to Lack of HTTPS Session Reuse
issues.body:
**Description**
When using the ElevenLabs TTS model for streaming, there is significant latency (~1000 ms) observed before the first word is streamed. This latency occurs even when multiple predictions are made in quick succession.

Upon reviewing the [ElevenLabs Latency Documentation](https://elevenlabs.io/docs/developer-guides/reducing-latency?utm_source=chatgpt.com), it is mentioned that reusing HTTPS sessions for WebSocket streaming can mitigate this issue. Specifically, reusing an SSL/TLS session allows subsequent requests to skip the handshake process, reducing latency.

However, there appears to be no straightforward way to reuse the session for multiple predictions, which forces each request to undergo a full handshake, leading to repeated high latency.

**Steps to Reproduce**
Use the ElevenLabs TTS API to stream a response for a prediction.
Send another prediction within the same application context.
Observe that the handshake process is repeated, causing ~1000 ms latency before the first word is streamed.
Expected Behavior
Subsequent predictions should reuse the same HTTPS session established during the first request, skipping the handshake process and reducing the latency for streaming responses.

**Actual Behavior**
Each prediction initiates a new HTTPS handshake, resulting in a ~1000 ms latency before streaming begins.

**Impact**
This significantly affects real-time applications that rely on low-latency TTS responses, such as voice assistants or live feedback systems.

Suggested Fix or Improvement
Provide an option or mechanism in the SDK or API to reuse HTTPS sessions for WebSocket streaming. This would allow subsequent predictions to benefit from an already established SSL/TLS session, thus improving the latency for all requests after the first one
issues.author: narendra-bluebash

comments.author: narendra-bluebash
comments.body: currently geeting approx 500 ms latency in when i yeild the first word to betwen the agent speak so i am saying how to use the perious session so that it will syas in 100 ms

comments.author: davidzhao
comments.body: we are using their websocket interface. the same HTTPSession is always reused.

I'm unable to reproduce the latency you are experiencing. I'm seeing 350ms TTFB with 11labs, connecting from my laptop in US West.

the latency you are seeing is not related to HTTPS negotiations, that only happens upfront.

issues.title: Feature Request: Allow Selective Track Subscription for VoiceAssistant
issues.body:
Description: Currently, the VoiceAssistant automatically subscribes to all participant audio tracks when instantiated, even when AutoSubscribe.SUBSCRIBE_NONE is used. This behavior prevents the ability to selectively subscribe to specific tracks and ignore others.

In use cases like the WebRTC web app, there is a need for the voice assistant to subscribe only to a specific participant's audio track, while ensuring that the other participant cannot hear the audio. The track should have a unique identifier (e.g., a custom name) so that the agent can subscribe to it while other participants' audio is ignored.

Proposed Solution: It would be beneficial if the VoiceAssistant instance could support more granular control over track subscriptions. Specifically, adding a feature to allow the agent to subscribe to specific tracks based on a unique identifier, while ignoring other tracks.

This would allow better flexibility in managing track subscriptions and would be especially useful for applications where private communication with the agent is required without broadcasting audio to other participants.

Use Case:

In a WebRTC web app, a user can interact with the voice assistant while ensuring the other participant does not hear the audio.
The agent can subscribe to a participant's specific audio track using its unique name or identifier, while other tracks are ignored.
Benefits:

Enhanced control over which audio tracks the agent subscribes to.
Improved privacy and user experience in scenarios with multiple participants.
Would love to see this functionality added to the VoiceAssistant!
issues.author: boussaidev
